comments.commentBody:
Surveillance should be the least of the concerns for Americans in the Post-Obama era.

President Obama has targeted and killed three American citizens without reasonable suspicion or probable cause. Anwar al-Awlaki and Samir Khan were grown men allegedly involved in propaganda and recruitment. Abdulrahman a--Awlaki was a 16 year old boy who did not pick his father Anwar. Instead of kidnapping, torture and indefinite detention, non-American citizens inside of foreign sovereign countries with who America is not at war are targeted and killed by cyber and drone wars.

In the new cyber age no one could have predicted that a vernacular black brother would become an Orwellian nightmare "Big Brother".

Spying on any and every American without any reasonable suspicion or probable cause is the data means towards what ends? And at what costs? Any and everything that America does in the realms of surveillance can and will be done by other nations against their own citizens and foreigners including Americans.

What's much more important than this topic is of course ex-beauty pageant queens and what Trump refers to parts of the female anatomy as.
Distraction after distraction, away from real, important issues seems to be the campaign tactic this season. Look! a squirrel!

Privacy is gone for good. Kiss it goodbye. Can't put that back into the bottle.
We opened a Pandora's Box after 9/11. Our Orwellian existence will continue unabated. Don't even THINK of wanting to change it. But don't let that stop you from using all that social media, emails (yahoo.), smart phones, home computers, credit cards, GPS, travels (EZ pass/TSA).
Your movements, every minute of every day are easily traced and accessible. To think otherwise is ignorant.

I remember once during Vietnam Johnson telling the Pentagon to send him all the important information they had, So they did, including the menus, the basketball schedules, the weather reports, everything. Johnson soon relented. I'd like to see us try something similar with the Russians. Bury the bums in everything we have at the weather bureau and they'll soon be sorry they ever started with us.

As an expatriate American automatically under surveillance by US guidelines, I resent my governments stealing my privacy. All my phone calls and e-mails are monitored by NSA or another oversight entity. Snowden wasn't lying.

The current presidential campaign offers no reassurance that the American government will be in good hands in March. The US has almost 20 trillion dollars of debt and is broke. Congress is in a permanent war with the president and may continue that war with the next president.

My escape to Provence is not complete as long as my life is still controlled by the American government!

If the technology is available it will be used; we're way beyond Democracy now; this is just Prole Control, a highly lucrative growth industry eagerly serving with every possible manufactured justification both government and private commercial interests.

Google and every online retailer knows as much about us as the gov't.  The best way to preserve our real freedom is to follow the law.  If we think something is wrong, work to change it.  The sad truth in today's world is that we have to have intense surveillance to keep the bad guys away--think Russia for now.

Spying on everybody is one thing, but people should be more private if they don't want their private lives to be available.  For example,the general public wouldn't actually know what Trump said about grabbing a woman's crotch if he didn't say it into a microphone.

Why is it that no important political figure in the US and few members of the press want to discuss this subject at all? I honestly don't think I know, but the silence is as ominous as the surveillance and makes me fear that there are very dark forces at work.

After I read this editorial I checked the "Ghostery" add-on to my Firefox browser and found that 20 organizations are monitoring this morning's digital experience at this time. For their own reasons they will analyze, package and sell my information to other interested parties. We all must guard our digital information against viruses, malware, cookies, spyware, phishing, and remote control of our computers. We worry about our credit card, bank and financial account security, our IRS refunds, and ID theft.

Edward Snowden has revealed that the national security authorities have collected enormous amounts of communications data on all Americans and that a secret FISA court has formulated its own body of law.

Even a literal reading of the Constitution's Fourth Amendment would make much of this data collection in violation of the law. For those who have not read the Constitution lately it states:

'The right of the people to be secure in their persons, houses, papers, and effects, against unreasonable searches and seizures, shall not be violated, and no Warrants shall issue, but upon probable cause, supported by Oath or affirmation, and particularly describing the place to be searched, and the persons or things to be seized."

We have "discoverable" subpoenable location data on our smartphone records and police are testing drones that can monitor our movements and driving behavior as part of "law enforcement."

The Fourth Amendment has not been repealed, just violated.

comments.userLocation: Fair Verona where we lay our scene
comments.commentBody:
I love the surprised TV camera in the drawing.

Of course The Man Who Will Lower The Sea Levels never thought twice about scaling back the secrecy & intel mavens in the spying agencies. That constitutes Power over People - and angry Barack has never once cut back on the power of government, regardless of his promises.

As Hillary told the bankers on Wall Street, you HAVE to lie, even if you didn't think you'd have to. There's the campaign promise and the public policy on each issue, and then there's the quiet, secret policy that builds up more Power in the Executive Branch.

This is her advantage over the Republicans. As a congenital liar, she pulls it of without even the smallest giveaway.

Given the latitude that is afforded to our NSA "friends", it's laughable to think they will ever go back to pretending they are protecting our privacy rights, let alone acknowledging them. This is what happens when goons are elected and given the keys to our democracy. And there is no irony in having another goon running for those keys...

The issue is bigger than just government overreach. A related question - exactly why does the NYTimes require me to disclose my (exact GPS) location in order to use the NYTimes APP? I'm a paying subscriber - so do not give me a targeted ad rationale. Shall we "just trust you?"

Who stands to gain, monetarily, from endess war, terror, and chaos? I can tell you for certain it isn't people who wake up, go to work, get their hands dirty, pay their taxes and follow the rules.
It is bankers, lawyers, munitions makers, spies, black ops mercs, and countless other worthless parasites who do zip-zilch-nada to make anyone's life better.
We need a people's revolution where 80% of the DOD budget is used for high-speed rail, bridge repair, public health, and anything else that makes law-abiding citizens gain access to a better life. Oh, and private helipads, those will be history.

As I understand it, 90% of our intelligence gathering apparatus has been privatized. That's insane! Just as we are now phasing out the privatizing of federal prisons, contractors like Booze Allen should be significantly divested of their role in intelligence gathering and intelligence work be brought back into the government fold.

Few people involved in this issue are considering the atrocious risk involved in the cross-adoption of social media marketing and governmental surveillance.

This is a country where the NSA is incompetent to the point of forgetting its own hacking network parked on others' servers, so lax that law enforcement regularly uses surveillance for personal purposes, and oblivious to the intrusion of social media's marketing such that people don't flinch at real-time targeted ads stemming from the text of intimate chat apps. The convergence is already emerging as political parties access social media marketing databases. The next step is governmental vending of surveillance data.

Wait for it:

"You said in your email that you'd voted for Hillary, so can we sell you a new yoga mat? Your parking-ticket profile suggests you'd be better to buy it online."

Look at the Bill of Rights, which the government has been flaunting since 9/11 in order to fight terrorism, all the while fanning the flames of terrorism instead. Try taking those rights and precedent seriously. We have fundamentally changed who we are, what kind of government we have, and obtained no benefit. The Constitution is a vestige, a joke. We have government authorities now suggesting that school teachers report students who question the government. We have militarized police who kill within seconds of encountering an individual who maybe has broken tail light. We are moving swiftly toward a police state without any individual rights at all, except perhaps for multi-millionaires.

American citizens have numerous layers of constitutional protections against the misuse of any information the government may accidentally obtain about them. Conversely, the ability of that government to gather critical intelligence about potentially devastating attacks is one of the few real protections Americans have against a growing list of potential catastrophes. The reach of terrorists and dictators has been greatly enhanced by low cost, widely available tools like encryption, drone technology and hacking. We can't afford to severely handcuff our own institutions in an increasingly dangerous, techno war environment. Our constitutional democracy enables us to eventually discover and stem any abuse. Americans should fear their true enemies far more than the institutions over which they have such a complete level of constitutionally protected control.

Privacy is a thing of the past already. If you carry a cellphone, there is a record of where you have been. The new system of toll collection going in on the Mass Pike is only the beginning of total surveillance practically anywhere most of the time.

"Balance between privacy and security." Such a meaningless phrase. Journalists, pundits, "experts", politicians use it without thinking about what it really means.

There is no "balance" to strike. It really comes down to this - do you have privacy in your life, or don't you? Is the government allowed to have access into every corner of people's thoughts and movements and experiences, or are they forced to use other forms of investigation to get information they might need, but keeping paramount the true meaning of a free society? Do we live in an increasingly, somewhat benign totalitarian system or one of liberty? You can't have both.

The surveillance industry has grown way out of proportion to any legitimate need. Billions are spent collecting data beyond any ability to make use of it intelligently. Cameras everywhere tracking and recording, compiling analytics, online, phones, profiles on millions if not billions - take a step back and look at it objectively and it's terrifying as well as unnecessary.

19 men hijacked some planes with a small support staff. In reaction to that, we now are monitored 24/7 - across the globe with ever-increasing secrecy and complexity and by people who have routinely broken the few "privacy laws" still in place.

Security is certainly at stake, but it's security from the power of the government and its agents to peer into our lives and annotate what they find, not some mythic terrorist beast.
Of more importance than what the Government absorbs from the public is what it says to the public through it's in-the-pocket Television networks and other media.

Who would have thought that the New York Times editoral board was in dire need of a high school civics lesson.

Because, while the president certainly has some powers when it comes to how these mechanisms there is a very "minor" item called "the law," which is something Congress is responsible for drafting, voting on and passing it to the president for his signature.

Likewise, the editorial board is in desperate need of a collective cup of java, since it has been asleep during the last six years when we have seen a GOP Congress that most would say is "slightly" obstructionist.

I think we should know what we are getting in exchange for our privacy, but of course the government will never tell us; as Mark Tomason has written, they get to keep their secrets while we have lost that right. Some sort of annual report should be required to let us know if ANYTHING useful was discovered. A good start would be the locked iPhone in Pasadena.

We should keep in mind, however, that Americans (all westerners) have given corporations complete access to their lives. This will be expanded if we go to a cash-less society as advocated in this week's New Yorker magazine.

Government snooping may be necessary in this angry world, but the capacity of the private sector to invade our privacy is totally out of control. The border control here and in other countries,  police departments around the country, potential employer, insurance companies and banker can easily know about our past mistakes and often used them to influence decision in our daily lives.  Do you really trusted business man Trump and others more with your secretes than your elected government?

"There is no security." A line from an old movie that still defines the surveillance reality, on both sides of the coin. The FBI's outrageous attempts to force Apple to invent software to corrupt its own products was just the tip of the iceberg. The FISA "star chamber" courts are just another example of the government's attempts, usually after the fact, and always in secret, to override any pesky laws that may impede "intelligence" agencies as they gather information.
What's clear is the ongoing evolution of encryption software and countermeasure software is perceived as a game, a game that has an abstract fascination strong enough to force logical concerns about "privacy" to the sidelines. There will be no end to this conflict. The obvious losers are citizens, futilely expecting some constitutional protections from the same agencies obsessed with reaping all digital information we create or possess.
Ironically, the next president could very likely be the person charged with either a blase ignorance of security protocols, or a technical ignorance that makes future decisions in this area "questionable", at best.
